messageBody:
Alexandru Popescu wrote:
> -----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
> Hash: SHA1
>
> [quote J. B. Rainsberger::on 2/4/2005 5:49 PM]
> | Shane Mingins wrote:
> |>
> |> --- "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@...> wrote:
> |>
> |> >
> |> > To solve the problem, testFindAll() should set up
> |> > the data it needs in
> |> > the database, so that it controls the expected
> |> > outcome. This is an
> |> > important trait of any good test, and not just tests
> |> > that use a database.
> |>
> |> I preface this question with "I know very little about
> |> EJB's"
> |>
> |> Is it possible to implement the findAll logic in a
> |> POJO which is then easier to test? Or is the code
> |> likely to be just a call to an EJB API?
> |
> | It's certainly possible. Typically all one needs to do is pass in the
> | DataSource or Connection to the POJO and off you go.
> |
>
> This in case you are doing BMP and not CMP. You must correctly evaluate
> the costs on this option.

Of course, Alex is right. With CMP there is no real value in trying to
test outside the container. As I wrote in _JUnit Recipes_, you might as
well run those tests against a live database, but run them less
frequently than the rest. Put them in a separate test suite and run them
in the background with CruiseControl. Otherwise, only run them if you
think you've changed something that might make them fail.

And, as always, when you don't run all the tests all the time, proceed
with caution.
